wikitext.*:
'''Dunlendish''',<ref name="Hobbits">{{App|Hobbits}}, p. 1130</ref> also known as the '''Dunland tongue''',<ref name="Deep">{{TT|Deep}}, p. 537</ref> was a [[Mannish]] [[Languages|language]] that was spoken by the [[Dunlendings]] of [[Dunland]].<ref name="Men">{{App|Men}}, p. 1130</ref>

==History==
The [[Pre-Númenórean]] language that was spoken by ancestors of the Dunlendings in the forests south of the [[Blue Mountains]] in [[Minhiriath]] and [[Enedwaith]] during the [[Second Age]]<ref>{{PM|Atani}}</ref> was related to the language of the [[Haladin|Folk of Haleth]] of the [[First Age]].<ref>{{PM|XNotes}}, note 72 and note 69</ref> The language of the Folk of Haleth was not related to the language of the [[House of Hador|Folk of Hador]] and the [[House of Bëor|Folk of Bëor]] from which [[Adûnaic]], the language of the [[Númenóreans]] was descended.<ref name="Atani">{{PM|Atani}}, including Note 72</ref> Dunlendish was not related to or only remotely akin to [[Westron]],<ref name="Men" /> because Westron was descended from Adûnaic mingled with many words of the languages of other Men.<ref>{{App|Men}}, p. 1129</ref>

It appears that a language related to Dunlendish was adopted by the southern group of [[Hobbits]] of [[Stoors|Stoor-kind]] while they settled between [[Tharbad]] and the borders of Dunland<ref>{{FR|Hobbits}}, p. 3</ref> between {{TA|1150}} until about {{TA|1630|n}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1150, p. 1085 and entry for the year ''c. '' 1630, p. 1086</ref> before they migrated north to [[the Shire]], but by the later [[Third Age]] their descendants in the Shire and in [[Bree]] had long abandoned it for the [[Westron|Common Speech]].<ref name="Hobbits" />

The [[Men of Bree]] once spoke a language that was related to Dunlendish, because they were descended from the same [[Pre-Númenóreans|people]] as the Dunlendings, but the Men of Bree adopted [[Westron]] after they became subjects of the kingdom of [[Arnor]].<ref name="Men" /> The odd names of [[Bucklanders]] and the name of Bree and the names of locations near Bree were traces of the older language of the southern Stoors and the Men of Bree.<ref name="Translation">{{App|Translation}}, p. 1135</ref>

On 3 March {{TA|3019}},<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3019, March 3, p. 1093</ref> during the [[War of the Ring]] [[Gamling]] said that Dunlendish was once spoken in many western valleys in [[Rohan]] and was able to understand Dunlendish.<ref name="Deep" /> It is not recorded if Dunlendish was still spoken by some inhabitants of Rohan as a native language at that time and how Gamling learned Dunlendish.

Apparently Dunlendish was known also beyond the other side of the [[Misty Mountains]]; the [[Great Gates]] of [[Moria]] included Dunlendish inscriptions in [[Cirth]].<ref>{{PM|XNotes}}, note 8</ref>

To this language belongs the name ''[[Forgoil]]'', which was said to mean 'Strawheads' and was given to the [[Rohirrim]],<ref name="Men">{{App|Men}}, p. 1130</ref> and was used as an insult during the battle of Helm's Deep.<ref name="Deep" />  The only analysis that can be done with some degree of credibility, is that the final part -il could be the plural marker of the word; then, it would be reminiscent to the [[Elvish]] partitive plural -li, and perhaps related.<ref>{{webcite|website=Arda|articleurl=https://folk.uib.no/hnohf/mannish.htm|articlename=Mannish|accessed=27 February 2019}}</ref>

==Translation==
[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] used [[Celtic]] names for many first names of male Hobbits of [[Buckland]] and for place names in the region of Bree.<ref name="Translation" />
